{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3383564,"name":"Vidhi Desai","username":"Vidhi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vidhi/{size}/222578_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T12:29:20.037Z","cooked":"

Hello Chief Delphi! My team is looking at submitting for the animation awards for 2025, and I’m looking for some advice on the awards, just in general, or if possible, some useful links. We’ve decided on using blender and/or stop motion for the process. For anyone interested, I’m attaching the links to both the pages below:

FIRST – 27 Oct 16

Digital Animation Award sponsored by AutomationDirect.com

Do you have awesome animation skills? Check out this award!

FIRST – 7 Dec 15

Safety

Instilling a culture of safety is a value that every individual in the FIRST community must embrace as we pursue FIRST’s mission and vision. FIRST Robotics Competition has adopted safety as a core value and has established the framework for safety...

And the relevant tags are all attached to this post!

Inside the links are YouTube playlists for all of the past winners.

Thank you!!!

I’ve pretty recently taken the plunge and learned Blender. I love it! Following along with Blender Guru’s donut tutorial was the best way for me to get comfortable with blender, I highly recommend it.

Some advice I have:

  • Practice animating and modeling now, even if just short 5 second animations.
  • Create some basic but useful assets (models, textures, materials, etc.) now.
    • Tools
    • Last year’s robot or a flat bot
    • 3D team logo
  • Practice writing outlines and / or drawing story boards so you can better plan your future animation
  • Lastly, the donut tutorial is super useful and I highly recommend for beginners!
","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-10T18:51:58.401Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":130,"readers_count":129,"score":36.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465856,"topic_slug":"animation-advice-and-links","display_username":"The Imagery Queen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30242,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"The Imagery Queen"},"post_url":"/t/animation-advice-and-links/465856/3","custom_user_title":"The Imagery Queen","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3385079,"name":"","username":"four","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/four/{size}/199902_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-13T00:05:53.442Z","cooked":"

One great resource is Sheepit. This is a free render farm that uses distributed computing. Even if you have the power to render everything yourself, chances are that you will not be ready to render until the end when time is tight. With Sheepit, you will still spend time rendering, but you can be banking that time all year until you need it. There is also a team functionality where all users in a team will prioritize rendering each other’s projects. You can join the ‘FRC Computing Power’ team if you want some additional power to your own devices (it is only me in there at the moment, but that is more than nothing).

If you intend to use a rigged character, start working on that now. These can be very difficult if it is anything other than a human or cat.

One resource for assets that I like is Sketchfab. They have a good number of Creative Commons assets.

Also think about sound. Animations usually have sound to go along with them. For music: https://freepd.com/, https://incompetech.com/ and the Youtube Music Library. For sound effects: https://freesound.org/, https://mixkit.co/free-sound-effects/

Look at your hardware situation. If you are going to be rendering in EEVEE, a CPU will probably be fine, but if you intend to do any serious Cycles work, a dedicated GPU (preferably Nvidia) will be needed unless you are generating Sheepit points on CPU for a long time.

If you have not used blender that much yet, make sure to use hotkeys as you learn. It will save a lot of time later.

When rendering, it is best to render each frame as a png and then combine them as an image sequence. This way, if the render crashes, you do not lose hours of work.

As others have said, learn to model, but also keep track of scale. The default cube that you see in the workspace is 2m * 2m * 2m. If the scale gets too unrealistically big, there can be issues with the viewport getting stuck when far from the origin and the camera needing to have an incredibly wide lens.

Finally, watch your pacing. Safety animation is 40s, Digital is 30s. That is not much time and you probably cannot fit everything you want to. Good pacing is hard, but cramming too much in will make it seem rushed and the judges will not be able to remember things if they only happen briefly and then a bunch of other things also happen, briefly.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-13T15:19:37.354Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":54,"readers_count":53,"score":15.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":465856,"topic_slug":"animation-advice-and-links","display_username":"Matthew / 8866 / Machinist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64023,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Blender enthusiast"},"post_url":"/t/animation-advice-and-links/465856/5","custom_user_title":"Blender enthusiast","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3425104,"name":"Sean Oyama","username":"seanoyama","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seanoyama/{size}/232704_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-19T01:54:30.250Z","cooked":"

This will be my 4th year leading my team’s animations. Putting aside technical skills like Blender or stop-motion, here’s what I learned along the way:

  • Start ASAP. You have about 2 months to complete your project, and you should use the generous amount of time to your own advantage, just like you would during the build season. Make a schedule and don’t procrastinate, because that will break the whole balance!
  • Spend a lot of time brainstorming and polishing your story. We spend the majority of our time laying out exactly what our vision is for the animation. It starts with simply writing out story ideas, then making character designs, then storyboarding. Once it’s all planned, make a list of every asset you need to make (characters, objects, background art, etc.).
  • Plan the timing. This is VERY important because there are strict rules on how long each part of the video can be. Make sure you know how long the intro/credits are, and whether that counts toward the 30-second limit of the animation. The rules have been adjusted in different years so stay updated.

Coordinating with your collaborators is also crucial to making the best possible animation.

  • Visual artists: Whether it’s 2D or 3D, or landscapes or characters, make sure the artists have a clear idea on what they are working on.
  • Music: If you are considering adding music, you always have the option to find music online. But if you have a composer on your team, they can make a soundtrack that fits your animation just right! We had a composer for the last 2 years, and I learned that it’s not as simple as making the scenes and adding sounds to it. We communicated on what frame rates to use, and I laid out the storyboard and set how much time will be spent on each scene, so both are in sync.

Edit: also, think of what style works for your team the best. I chose to use simple pixel art textures and low-poly meshes so I can run it fine on my laptop at home.

Last but not least, make sure everyone is having fun! In the end this is a way to express your creative side, and this should be the calm before kickoff.
I’m considering making a video breaking down our past submissions if you’d be interested.
Good luck, would love to see your final product!
